title: How hard is it to do a simple color swap on abilities?
body:
I mean, this is a serious question. **Not at all trying to be offensive** because I honestly have no knowledge of creating skins or anything of the sort, but with these new skins coming out for Ezreal, Mordekaiser, Shaco and Syndra, you would think that there would be a little more drastic changes.

Simply put, I'm not asking for a giant change like a legendary skin or anything like that, but how difficult is to just at least change the colors of the abilities. Syndra's spheres could be like pink or something, or even Shaco's clone something other than green. I know that this is still in PBE, so changes may not be final, but on a similar note I started getting upset about this when the Valentine's Day Annie skin came out. Tibbers and Annie both had nice new skins, but their abilities were exactly the same. If they had been at least a pink or yellow or something, I would have instantly bought.

I just think that the skins and splash art for these skins look amazing, but I don't find it worth spending money when things will be exactly the same. You came out with Chromas, is there anyway to implement that into particle effects or something?


**tl;dr -- I don't know how hard it is to make skins, but is it possible to do a little color change on the abilities of these new skins?**

replies.body:
Yo!

So there are several factors that prevent us from simply changing particle colors on skins. The first and biggest issue is time. We have a limited number of particle artist on the team, they are ALWAYS busy. You have to keep in mind that they are working on multiple skins at a time that range from Legendary to 975 RP skins. When someone says "Hey, just change the particles", that would require an artist to stop working on their current skin and start work on this new project. That takes time and it would break our schedule and cause multiple skins to be delayed. There are only so many hours in the day and only so many artists.

We plan out skins months in advance so we can create as many skins as possible each year and if that schedule gets interrupted by a delay there are ripple effects. :<

The 2nd issue is testing.  All of our skins go through rigorous testing and different test suites depending on the changes to the skin. 750 skins go through a smaller test suite that requires less time to complete due to the fact that fewer changes were made.  

We see it time and time again that the more changes we make to a skin the more bugs we find on that skin and on the older skins that champion has. Again we only have so many testers and so many hours in the day.

Additionally if we were to overhaul Syndra and make her a 975 she would have to go through testing all over again which would delay her greatly.

I don't care, delay it please.  This skin could be so nice, it would be a shame to see a great concept and model not used to its full potential.  Plus Shaco got a new box, why can't Syndra have the diamonds that were suggested in another thread?

#With all due respect, but...

>That takes time and it would break our schedule and cause multiple skins to be delayed. There are only so many hours in the day and only so many artists.

Nobody asks you to throw 10 half-baked quality skins at us every patch (like you were doing lately; not all of them, of course) if the quality will be so underwhelming maybe 5 people per region will buy them.

Hell, why did you shave QoD Syndra? **I bet it was faster to delete the hair mesh than to recolour it, am I right?**

>The 2nd issue is testing. All of our skins go through rigorous testing and different test suites depending on the changes to the skin. 750 skins go through a smaller test suite that requires less time to complete due to the fact that fewer changes were made. 

Testing? What testing? QoD Syndra skin has clipping issues. Just write /joke. Bam, it took me 2 seconds to find a thing to fix.

>Additionally if we were to overhaul Syndra and make her a 975 she would have to go through testing all over again which would delay her greatly.

**Do it. Quality over quantity.**

I mean, I know they're a business and ideally you want as much money earned for the minimum amount of money spent, but in this instance there seems to be a disconnect between Riots current values, and the customer expectations, which are the old values riot established.

It's harder than you think to test skins. They have to make sure the skin doesn't bug for not just one game but ALL Games at the same time forever. Let's say they do fix the clipping issue, they still have to go back and re check EVERTHING to make sure that the addition/removal of the code doesn't negatively affect anything else. And if it does they have to find some sort of alternate way to fix the clipping issue cause the previous way f**cked up with the pre existing code. And then rinse and repeat. It's most likely harder than u think

Everything? Because you made a slight tweak to the mesh? Not even close, sir.
Unless that's how their spaghetti code works.
A change in one thing can often effect something different.

For modifying a texture without changing it's size? That's a thing in only two cases:

1. You really screwed something up adding stuff and should re-evaluate your abilities.
2. Your code is so crappy, it's a miracle it works.

Plus if something is broken, you won't fix it, because it might show another problem? What kind of thinking is that suppose to be?

Yes, changes to one thing can effect another. However, that doesn't mean that's the case for all changes. 

What we're also talking about here is particles.  The OP even stated changing the colours of particles would be sufficient. 

For a simple particle recolour, you mainly would only be testing for clarity, both for regular players, and for colour blind players (which to be honest, they should already have tested for what colours are easy to see on the rift when they did their colour blind mode).

For new particle designs you could have bugs, but mainly it should be just changing the texture of the particle, and then adjusting the positioning to avoid clipping. You shouldn't be changing the coding of the abilities themselves to incorporate the texture.

I understand that there is only so much work that an artist can do at a time, but honestly I would much rather have an artist etc spend more time on a skin to really make it special than to just settle with a basic recolor. 

Going back to the Annie skin, I love sweetheart Annie but honestly I never use her because I'd much rather use one of the Annie skins that has different particles or ability colors. Having those changes makes it feel like an entirely new champion and makes the champion feel new and fresh. Casting the same abilities over and over with the same particles eventually gets a little boring to see and I end up losing interest in the champion, especially ones like ezreal who only has one skin that changes particles. I think putting in more work and time to produce higher quality skins would be better than just trying to turn out x number of skins in a certain time frame of those skins are just boring recolors that don't change the feel of the champion.

changing a particle's color doesn't really involve programming, you quite literally just need to open the .dds file of the particle in a program like photoshop and change the color (which is REALLY quick and easy). That's it.

In some specific cases it might take a little bit longer because of multi-textured particles (cho'gath's W, IIRC, has a file for the base white in it and a different one for the blue ripples, for example), in which case you'd have to recolor multiple files (unless you only want to change one of the multiple colors), but it's still something you can do in a couple of minutes as long as you know which files to change (and considering they work / make those skins, they _know_ which files to change)

as an example, here's the file that determines the color of jayce's hammer form particles (taken from debonair jayce, but it's the same as his base skin): (attached at the end of the post because I don't know how to put an image in the middle of the post)

I open it on photoshop, now press Ctrl + U to open a Hue/Saturation window, and can literally just move the Hue (color) slider to get, for example, Red particles for hammer-form jayce. Done.

That's how it works. Unless a skin has a changing model/textures, different number of particles or new voices and sounds that the base skin doesn't, there is little to zero programming involved - it basically ends the moment you add a new slot for a skin.
Then everything is in hands of the guy(s) making resources(models and textures) to not screw some basic stuff (everybody who ever cared how The Elder Scrolls work will know), but that's not programming.
---

PS. To put an image in the post you just need to copy-paste a link. It will either show full image or thumbnail depending on the size. You can also post your attached image the same way.

If you planned the skins with particle changes, there wouldn't be delays, since its planned. Likewise, testing would occur with those particle changes.

Yo AbyssionKnight!

We only plan for 750's to have no particle changes. 975 skins and higher are always planned to include new particle work and we schedule them accordingly.

Thanks for the response, Riot Galetta.

I think the misunderstanding here is on what the goal of a skin actually is. 

Your goal is to expand the 750rp line. You saw a champion, TF, who has a skin you could build a theme off of. That skin happens to have no particle effects, which makes it the perfect theme to use to for a 750 skin line (well, besides the fact Jack of Hearts TF is 520).

A player however buys a skin with the goal of fulfilling a fantasy. That might be a personal fantasy, or one they have for the champion itself. We also don't really care about your goal of keeping skins in a theme the same price, or even expanding skins in the 750 price range (which admittedly is amusing, considering the complaints about too many 1350 level skins and not enough cheaper ones). What we care about is the skin living up to it's maximum potential. 

So when we see a skin like Queen of Diamonds Syndra, that doesn't really have any diamonds involved (beyond jewellery and patterns on a dress), it's disappointing. Just making the balls red octahedra (3d diamonds) instead would have probably satisfied most people. Same if Ezrael had a more spade shape to his skills.

So from a player perspective we don't understand why you'd choose to make these 750 tier skins when they have clear potential to be better than that.

But here's the thing Galetta, we were told (just yesterday) that pricing doesn't come into thought until well down the line. So what is it? Early pricing a skin (and allocating the needed resources) or waiting until the skin teams sees how much work a skin is and then allocating the needed resources?

I don't buy skins without particle changes anymore.
It's not worth the price to me. 

Even if it's a simple enough particle change to only make it 975, something is better than nothing.

I think it's harder than it looks at first. People in boards have, for awhile, been showing up with their apparent "5 minutes in photoshop" changes to coloring on champs. I saw a blue Zac that was particularly bad, but the guy who made it seemed to think it was fine.

That's my deal. People who don't value the visuals or the art seem to think that this is an easy task; I just want a blue Zac, how hard could it possibly be? Well, when you care about the quality, pretty hard. It takes a while to do that kind of thing.

I've recently been spending some time learning how to make high quality figures of molecules for my own work. I've been floored by just how difficult it can be to display a simple molecule in a clear way, and the colors are actually the hardest part to get right (it's mostly the only part that I care about anyway). Now, the program I use (Diamond, for any curious chemists out there), lacks some features that would make this easier... but for me, the point stands. It doesn't look good if you just slap a blue filter on Zac's model and abilities. It takes real work if you want it to share the same high quality as the original model. 

From a business standpoint, Riot has no reason to hold back on this. If we show them, by spending money on those upcoming chromas, that we want this feature and are willing to make it worth their time, they will continue to provide it. But it's an investment.
